resource.description: The NCBI Taxonomy database contains the names of all organisms that are represented in the Entrez genetic databases.

The Sequence Ontology Project (SO) is a joint effort by genome annotation centres, including: WormBase, the Berkeley Drosophila Genome Project, FlyBase, the Mouse Genome Informatics group, and the Sanger Institute. They are a part of the Gene Ontology Project and their aim is to develop an ontology suitable for describing biological sequences.

ENZYME is a repository of information relative to the nomenclature of enzymes. It is primarily based on the recommendations of the Nomenclature Committee of the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB) and it describes each type of characterized enzyme for which an EC (Enzyme Commission) number has been provided
Gene Ontology annotation uses evidence codes to indicate the type of evidence that supports the annotation.

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: The Gene Ontology from Sep. 24, 2009
resource.description: The Gene Ontology (GO) project provides a controlled vocabulary to describe gene and gene product attributes in any organism.

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: The nr file from 2009-09-24
resource.description: The Non-Redundant Database (NRDB) of protein sequences in FASTA format from GenBank.
InterPro is a database of protein families, domains and functional sites in which identifiable features found in known proteins can be applied to unknown protein sequences.

resource.displayName: T. gondii GT1 protein GO Associations

resource.pluginArgs: --externalDatabaseSpec "%EXT_DB_NAME%|%EXT_DB_RLS_VER%" --inputFile @downloadDir@/GOAssociations_TG_GT1/gene_association.Tgondii.GT1 --goExternalDatabaseSpec "Gene Ontology|4.451" --seqIdSql "SELECT g.source_id, taf.aa_sequence_id FROM dots.genefeature g, dots.transcript t, dots.translatedAAFeature taf WHERE g.na_feature_id = t.parent_id AND t.na_feature_id = taf.na_feature_id" --targetTable "DoTS::TranslatedAASequence" --lineOfEvidence "JCVI" --inputIdColumn id --tolerateMissingSeqs --skipBadGOTerms @pipelineDir@/logs/badGOTerms.log

resource.displayName: T. gondii RH predicted full length transcripts

manualGet.institution: Department of Parasitology, Institute of Medical Science, University of Tokyo

resource.pluginArgs: --sourceIdRegex ">(\S+\(\w+\))$" --fastaFile @downloadDir@/WatanabeTgRH_PredictedTrancripts/reffull_tg.fas --externalDatabaseName %EXT_DB_NAME% --externalDatabaseVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --SOTermName 'transcript' --ncbiTaxId 383379 --libraryVector 'pME18SFL3' --contactName 'Junichi Watanabe' --contactAddress1 "Institute of Medical Science; The University of Tokyo, Department of Parasitology" --contactAddress2 "4-6-1, Shirokanedai, Minatoku, Tokyo 108-8639, Japan" --putativeFullLength --libraryStage 'tachyzoites' --libraryName 'derivedFromWatanabeTgRH' --libraryDesc "Predicted full length transcript sequence produced after BLAT alignment of the WatanabeTgRH EST library sequences to the genome and correction of the cDNA sequences using annotated gene sequences."
resource.description: T. gondii RH EST sequences (J. Watanabe, H. Wakaguri, M. Sasaki, Y. Suzuki, S. Sugano at Institute of Medical Science, University of Tokyo).

manualGet.institution: Department of Parasitology, Institute of Medical Science, University of Tokyo

resource.pluginArgs: --sourceIdRegex ">(\w+)$" --fastaFile @downloadDir@/WatanabeTgRH_EstLibrary/onepass_tg.fas --externalDatabaseName %EXT_DB_NAME% --externalDatabaseVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --SOTermName 'EST' --ncbiTaxId 383379 --libraryVector 'pME18SFL3' --contactName 'Junichi Watanabe' --contactAddress1 "Institute of Medical Science; The University of Tokyo, Department of Parasitology" --contactAddress2 "4-6-1, Shirokanedai, Minatoku, Tokyo 108-8639, Japan" --libraryName 'WatanabeTgRH' --libraryStage 'tachyzoites' --libraryDesc "Toxoplasma gondii RH tachyzoites were infected into Vero (T25) cells and incubated in EMEM medium supplemented with 8% fetal bovine serum for 72 hours in vitro. Infected cells were collected with a scraper and passed through 27G needle for three times and purified by filtration through Millex SV filters (pore size 5 um, Millipore). Cells were collected by centrifugation at 2,000 rpm for 10 min and washed in EMEM medium without FBS. Parasites were suspended at 1x107/ml in EMEM medium without FBS. Five-week old ICR female mice were infected with 1 ml parasites intraperitoneally.Three days after infection, mice were sacrificed by cervical dislocation. Parasites were collected by washing the peritoneal cavity with 5 ml EMEM, passed through 5 um filter, washed in PBS and suspended at 2-3x109 parasite/ml. 20 ml TRI REGENT (Sigma) was added to 1 ml parasite solution, mixed by pipetting, frozen in liquid nitrogen and kept at -80C until used."
resource.description: T. gondii RH predicted full length transcript sequences (J. Watanabe, H. Wakaguri, M. Sasaki, Y. Suzuki, S. Sugano at Institute of Medical Science, University of Tokyo).

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: MGED Ontology
resource.description: Concepts, definitions, terms, and resources for standardized description of a microarray experiment in support of MAGE v.1. The MGED ontology is divided into the MGED Core ontology which is intended to be stable and in synch with MAGE v.1; and the MGED Extended ontology which adds further associations and classes not found in MAGE v.1

resource.unpack: cat /files/cbil/data/cbil/toxoDb/manualDelivery/AnnotationFromJCVI/sequences_without_annotation/me49_id_mapping.tab | perl -e 'while(<STDIN>){chomp;my ($old, $new)=split(/\t/,$_);$old =~ s/^/TGG_/;$ids{$old} = $new;}; while(<>){if (/^(TGG_\d+)/ and $ids{$1}){ my $temp=$1;$_ =~ s/$1/$ids{$temp}/g;print $_;}}' @downloadDir@/ME49_Annotation/tgal_initial.gff> @downloadDir@/ME49_Annotation_fixed/tgal.gff
resource.pluginArgs: --extDbName %EXT_DB_NAME% --extDbRlsVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --seqExtDbName "T.gondii ME49 contigs from Genbank" --seqExtDbRlsVer "2008-07-23" --mapFile @gusHome@/lib/xml/isf/TIGRGffFeatures2gus.xml --inputFileOrDir @downloadDir@/ME49_Annotation_fixed/tgal.gff --fileFormat gff2 --soCvsVersion @soVer@ --defaultOrganism "Toxoplasma gondii ME49" --gff2GroupTag "GenePrediction" --naSequenceSubclass ExternalNASequence --seqIdColumn source_id --handlerExternalDbs "enzyme:enzymeDB:2009-09-24"

egrep 'Sibley' @downloadDir@/GeneticMarkers_Sibley_fixed/Tg10x_31-SibleySNPs.formatted.gff | perl -e 'while(<>) { chomp; my @line = split("\t", $_); $line[8] =~ s/SNP/ID/; my $line = join("\t",@line); print "$line\n";}'> @downloadDir@/GeneticMarkers_Sibley_fixed/Tg10x_31-SibleySNPs.fixed.gff

resource.displayName: Expression profiling of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages
resource.extDbName: Expression profiling of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages
resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Expression profiling of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages

manualGet.institution: Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania

resource.description:
Expression profiling of two strains from each of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages was generated as per the following experiment:
At least three T25 flasks containing confluent monolayers of human foreskin fibroblasts grown in D10 media were infected with approximately 1x107 T. gondii tachyzoite parasites per strain. After 6hrs, the media was replaced with fresh D10. Approximately 40hr post-infection (and prior to observable host cell lysis), media was removed and flasks were washed once with 1x cold PBS. Cell monolayers were scraped in 5ml 1x cold PBS, and centrifuged for 12min, 750g at 4C. Supernatant was removed, and RNA was isolated from the cell pellets using Qiagen RNEasy kit according to manufacturer's instructions.
Strains utilized:
Type I:   RH and GT1
Type II:  Pru and ME49
Type III: CTG and VEG
This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication by Paul Davis and David Roos.

manualGet.institution: Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania

resource.pluginArgs: --extDbName %EXT_DB_NAME% --extDbRlsVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --seqExtDbName "T.gondii ME49 contigs from Genbank" --seqExtDbRlsVer "2008-07-23" --mapFile @gusHome@/lib/xml/isf/TIGRGffFeatures2gus.xml --inputFileOrDir @downloadDir@/ME49_GLEAN_fixed/Tg10x_31-GLEAN.gff --fileFormat gff2 --soCvsVersion @soVer@ --defaultOrganism "Toxoplasma gondii ME49" --gff2GroupTag "GenePrediction" --naSequenceSubclass ExternalNASequence --seqIdColumn source_id --handlerExternalDbs "enzyme:enzymeDB:2008-07-01"
resource.description: GLEAN is an automated gene predictor that integrates different evidence of gene structure to produce a consensus gene. For more informtaion click here or to download GLEAN click here. Gene predictions for T. gondii produced by GLEAN, provided by Aaron Mackey, David Roos (University of Pennsylvania).

resource.unpack: cat /files/cbil/data/cbil/toxoDb/manualDelivery/AnnotationFromJCVI/sequences_without_annotation/me49_id_mapping.tab | perl -e 'while(<STDIN>){chomp;my ($old, $new)=split(/\t/,$_);$ids{$old} = $new;}; while(<>){if (/^(\d+)/ and $ids{$1}){ my $temp=$1;$_ =~ s/$1/$ids{$temp}/g;print $_;}}' @downloadDir@/ME49_TwinScanEt/Tg10x_31-TwinScanEt.gff> @downloadDir@/ME49_TwinScanEt_fixed/Tg10x_31-TwinScanEtNewID.gff

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: T. gondii cosmid ends
resource.description:
Sequence from cosmid ends mapped against T. gondii ME49, VEG and GT1 scaffolds.
End-sequence data from cosmid clones were provided by Ian Paulsen at TIGR. Sequencing was done using T3 and T7 primers represented as TH and TV, respectively, in the sequence IDs.
Cosmids with the TOX designation originated from Boris Striepen's laboratory, while those that start with PSB are from David Sibley's group. A detailed description of cosmid libararies from the Sibley lab is available here.

resource.displayName: TgonME49 Cosmid Ends from Hernan Lorenzi

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Mass Spec data from Silvia Moreno-1 DTASelect filter
resource.description:
Proteomics data provided by Silvia Moreno's lab from the University of Georgia, Athens, GA. Two data sets (samples A and G) were graciously provided pre-publication. Samples were prepared from RH parasites by Silvia Moreno's laboratory at the University of Georgia, Athens, GA and analyzed by James Thompson and John Yates, III at The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA.
This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication by Silvia Moreno (smoreno@cb.uga.edu).

Chromosome map generated by David Sibley for T. gondii ME49 strain was used as a template to creat T. gondii GT1 chromosomes. Chromosomes we assembled by the EuPathDB team using .

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation data from Kami Kims lab
resource.description:
Chromatin Immunoprecipitation chip data identifying regions of active transcription. This data was generated by Mathieu Gissot, J. Eduardo Fajardo, Louis M. Weiss, Andras Fiser, Kami Kim Albert Einstein College of Medicine, This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication. Peak calls were made by the data provider.
Contact Kami Kim, kkim@aecom.yu.edu, for further information

resource.displayName: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation Microarray for Called Peaks
resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation called peak data from Kami Kims lab
resource.description: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation chip data identifying regions of active transcription. Peak calls were made by the data provider.

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation data from Hakimi
resource.description: Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and microarray hybridization (Nimblegen arrays), we analyzed the patterns ofDNA-bound Histone H4(K5-K8-K12-K16) acetylation after 4 hours treatment of RH strain with DMSO (control) or 40 nM of FR235222 (named previously drug A) which is a Toxoplasma-specific HDAC inhibitor. ChIP-on-chip isolated DNA samples (input and immunopurified DNA) were arrayed on custom synthetic oligo arrays (387,000 features per array, 46-50 mer oligos, 2 arrays for the whole genome; Nimblegen). Peak calls were made by the data provider. Data provided by Mohamed-Ali Hakimi, Institut Jean Roget.

resource.displayName: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation Microarray for Called Peaks - Hakimi
resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation called peak data from Hakimi
resource.description: Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and microarray hybridization (Nimblegen arrays), we analyzed the patterns ofDNA-bound Histone H4(K5-K8-K12-K16) acetylation after 4 hours treatment of RH strain with DMSO (control) or 40 nM of FR235222 (named previously drug A) which is a Toxoplasma-specific HDAC inhibitor. ChIP-on-chip isolated DNA samples (input and immunopurified DNA) were arrayed on custom synthetic oligo arrays (387,000 features per array, 46-50 mer oligos, 2 arrays for the whole genome; Nimblegen). Peak calls were made by the data provider.

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Toxoplasma centromere peaks from Einstein|2009-06-18
resource.pluginArgs: --extDbName %EXT_DB_NAME% --extDbRlsVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --mapFile @gusHome@/lib/xml/isf/ToxoDB/toxoFeatures2gus.xml --inputFileOrDir @downloadDir@/Einstein_Centromeres/jb_called_centromeres.gff --fileFormat gff2 --gff2GroupTag ID --naSequenceSubclass VirtualSequence --seqIdColumn source_id --seqExtDbName "Chromosome Map - David Sibley" --seqExtDbRlsVer "2008-08-28" --soCvsVersion @soVer@ --defaultOrganism "Toxoplasma gondii" --handlerExternalDbs "enzyme:enzymeDB:2008-07-01" --bioperlTreeOutput @pipelineDir@/logs/toxoCentromeres.bioperl
resource.description:
Identification Toxoplasma gondii centromeres was performed by ChIP-chip using antibodies to Centromeric Histone 3 (CenH3-HA) colocalized with antibodies to H3K9me2.
For further information please contacts Kami Kim (kkim@aecom.yu.edu) or Boris Striepen (striepen@cb.uga.edu).

resource.displayName: T. gondii M4 Fritz/Buchholz Array Profiles
resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Expression profiling of Tgondii ME4 Boothroyd data
resource.description:
Transcriptome analysis of oocyst,tachyzoite and bradyzoite development in the type II strain M4.

There were three primary objectives to the overall experiment.

     I. Describe the transcriptome of the oocyst through its development beginning with the freshly excreted, unsporulated oocyst at "Day 0" to a fully sporulated and mature oocyst at "Day 10" and including a mid-sporulation time-point at "Day 4".
     II. Compare the transcriptomes of in vitro (4 and 8 days post infection (dpi)) vs. in vivo (21 dpi) derived bradyzoites.
     III. Compare expression data from three life stages (oocyst, bradyzoite and tachyzoite) from the same parasite isolate, M4. This isolate has been characterized as a Type II strain.

The RNA was derived from parasites donated by the Moredun Research Intstitute, Edinburgh, Scotland, UK and belong to the same original isolate (T. gondii M4: J. Gutierrez et al. Veterinary Parasitology 172 (2010) 8-15.)

More specifically, RNA samples were obtained from:

     1. Oocysts harvested from kitten feces and purified for RNA extraction at Day 0, (not sporulated), Day 4 post-induction of sporulation (mid-sporulation) and Day 10 post-induction of sporulation. Oocysts were collected and combined from two kittens that were infected with the same starting material (mouse brains containing bradyzoite cysts). Duplicate samples were obtained from feces collected and purified on separate days.
     2. Bradyzoite cysts harvested from the brains of mice that were infected with oocysts (obtained from the oocysts harvested from kittens as described for the oocyst RNA). Mice were treated with 0.44 µg/ml sulfadiazine in their water days 11-21 pi to enable a chronic infection state. Mice were sacrificed on day 21 for cyst purification.
     3. In vitro 4 and 8 dpi bradyzoite and 2 dpi tachyzoite samples are from separately infected cultures of human foreskin fibroblasts (HFF) (replicate flasks for each condition and time-point were infected on the same day). Samples were harvested independently and kept separate for all the subsequent processing and labeling steps. Bradyzoite differentiation was induced by growth under low serum (1%) high pH (8.0) conditions without supplemented CO2 as described (Fux, B. et. al. Infect Immun 75:2580-90, 2007).

Authors: Heather Fritz*, Kerry R. Buchholz*, Patricia Conrad, and John C. Boothoryd. (* these authors contributed equally.)

resource.displayName: Tgondii VEG tachyzoite RNA-Seqs from Adam Reid
resource.extDbRlsDescrip: T.gondii VEG and N.caninum RNASeq from Adam Reid
resource.description: Transcriptome analysis of T. gondii VEG and N. caninum Liverpool tachyzoites using RNAseq RNA sequencing data provided by Adam Reid, Mandy Sanders, Mike Quail, Matthew Berriman, Arnab Pain (Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute) Rebecca Norton, Dong Xia, Sarah Vermont and Jonathan Wastling (University of Liverpool). A paper describing our analysis of this data (Reid et al.) is currently in preparation.

resource.displayName: Toxoplasma gondii VAND contigs and scaffolds
resource.description: This assembly was sequenced at a ~40X coverage using both 454 and Illumina sequencing technology and assembled with Newbler. Genomic DNA was provided by Dr. David Sibley's laboratory and the sequence generated at the J. Craig Venter Institute. Users should acknowledge the J. Craig Venter Institute and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Department of Health and Human Services in any publications that result from use of this draft sequence assembly. Any investigators who propose to publish analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes on a genome scale should contact the J. Craig Venter Institute for the use of pre-publication data.

resource.displayName: Toxoplasma gondii p89 contigs and scaffolds
resource.description: This assembly was sequenced at a ~30X coverage using both 454 and Illumina sequencing technology and assembled with Newbler. Genomic DNA was provided by Dr. David Sibley's laboratory and the sequence generated at the J. Craig Venter Institute. Users should acknowledge the J. Craig Venter Institute and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Department of Health and Human Services in any publications that result from use of this draft sequence assembly. Any investigators who propose to publish analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes on a genome scale should contact the J. Craig Venter Institute for the use of pre-publication data.
